rule.name: are still the some (same)
rule.message: Did you mean \1 still the same or \1 still some?
rule.example: That means that tires are still the some of the most important components of your vehicle.
But it is still the some government.
That means that tires are still some of the most important components of your vehicle.
But it is still the same government.

rule.name: is even worst (worse)
rule.message: Probably incorrect use of superlative '\3'. Consider using the comparative form instead (e.g. 'better' instead of 'best').
rule.example: He was even worst after a year.
He was even worst.
He was even worse after a year.
He was even best man at my wedding.
He was even worse.

rule.name: de juro (jure)
rule.message: This is an incorrect spelling of a Latin phrase. Did you mean de jure?
rule.example: There is no de juro segregation allowed by law anywhere in the United States.
There is no de jure segregation allowed by law anywhere in the United States.

rule.name: I thin (think)
rule.example: I thin you are right.
How do I thin heavier acrylics for Airbrushing?
I think you are right.
How can I thin out my face?
Am I Thin Enough Yet?

rule.name: suppose to (supposed to)
rule.message: Probably you should use a past participle here: supposed.
rule.example: What jar is this suppose to be coming from?

rule.name: all be it (albeit)
rule.example: The good news is that there are several redeeming factors to (all be it barely).

rule.name: all for not (all for naught)
rule.message: Did you mean all for naught (=all for nothing)?
rule.example: Sorry all for not being in the chat.
My farmer pants were all for not...

rule.name: all over the word (all over the world)
rule.example: The company employs over 25 000 people all over the word.

rule.name: another words (in other words)
rule.message: Did you mean in other words?
rule.example: Another words, he is an ideal husband.

rule.name: back and fourth (back and forth)
rule.message: Did you mean back and forth?
rule.example: How to move back and fourth from linux to xmb?

rule.name: back in forth (back and forth)
rule.message: Did you mean back and forth?

I've been texting back and forth with him for the past 3 days

rule.name: bob/barb wire (barbed wire)

rule.message: Possible typo. Did you mean can?

rule.name: eye brow/lash/lid/sight/sore (eyebrow/eyelash/eyelid/eyesight/eyesore)

The consolation prize was a trip to the Bahamas.

rule.name: constitutes (consists) of
rule.example: The city constitutes of five boroughs.
The city consists of five boroughs.

rule.name: could (couldn't) care less
rule.message: Did you mean couldn't care less?
rule.example: The man on the street said he could care less.
The man on the street said he couldn't care less.

rule.name: could (couldn't) give a damn
rule.message: Did you mean couldn't give a damn?
rule.example: Frankly, my dear, I could give a damn.
Frankly, my dear, I couldn't give a damn.

rule.name: daily regiment (regimen)
rule.example: They had a strict daily regiment of calisthenics.
They had a strict daily regimen of calisthenics.

rule.name: de factor (facto)
rule.example: There was a de factor ban on cigarettes.
There was a de facto ban on cigarettes.

rule.name: worse-case (worst-case) scenario
rule.example: They always prepared for the worse-case scenario.
They always prepared for the worst-case scenario.

rule.name: worst (worse) comes to worst
rule.message: Did you mean worse comes to worst?
rule.example: If worst comes to worst, we'll just move.
If worse comes to worst, we'll just move.

rule.name: to bath (bathe)
rule.example: It's so relaxing to bath in the evening.
It's so relaxing to bathe in the evening.

rule.name: treasure trough (trove)
rule.example: In the wreckage they found a treasure trough of doubloons.
It was a treasure trove of ideas.

rule.name: ad nauseum (nauseam)
rule.example: The song was playing ad nauseum.
The song was playing ad nauseam.

rule.name: Noble (Nobel) Prize
rule.example: He was awarded the Noble Prize in literature.
He was awarded the Nobel Prize in physics.

rule.name: land lover (landlubber)
rule.example: The sailors considered John to be a serious land lover.
The sailors considered John to be a serious landlubber.

rule.name: strike a cord (chord)
rule.message: Did you mean strike a chord?
rule.example: Her comment happened to strike a cord with the colonel.
Her comment happened to strike a chord with the colonel.

rule.name: safety (safe) deposit box
rule.message: Did you mean safe deposit box?
rule.example: He inherited his grandfather's safety deposit box.
He inherited his grandfather's safe deposit box.

rule.name: statue (statute) of limitations
rule.message: Did you mean statute of limitations?
rule.example: Luckily, his crime wasn't covered by the statue of limitations.
He was one year away from the statute of limitations.

rule.name: all the farther (as far as)
rule.message: Did you mean as far as?
rule.example: The town was all the farther than the border.
The town was as far as the border.

rule.name: discussions around (about)
rule.example: They had many discussions around politics.
They had many discussions about politics.

rule.name: as time progressed (passed)
rule.message: Did you mean as time passed?
rule.example: As time progressed, the sisters got wiser.
As time passed, the sisters got wiser.

rule.name: as follow (follows)
rule.example: The main points are as follow:
The main points are as follows:

rule.name: beyond the pail (pale)
rule.message: Did you mean beyond the pale?
rule.example: His behavior was beyond the pail.
His behavior was beyond the pale.

rule.name: beckon (beck and) call
rule.message: Did you mean beck and call?
rule.example: Don't expect me to be at your beckon call.
Don't expect me to be at your beck and call.

rule.name: begs (beggars) belief
rule.example: It begs belief that corporate policies can always pursue the best interests of a company.
It beggars belief that corporate policies can always pursue the best interests of a company.

rule.name: buttload (boatload)
rule.example: There was a buttload of cabbage left over.
There was a boatload of sprouts left over.

rule.name: brussell (brussells) sprout
rule.example: He left the last brussell sprout on his plate.
He left the last brussells sprout on his plate.

rule.name: bored of (with)
rule.example: I always get bored of people who talk about themselves.
I always get bored with people who talk about themselves.

rule.name: build off of (build on)
rule.example: Arcade Fire tried to build off of the success of their first album.
Arcade Fire tried to build on the success of their first album.

rule.name: trite (tried) and true
rule.message: Did you mean tried and true?
rule.example: It was a trite and true solution.
It was a tried and true solution.

rule.name: between you and I (me)
rule.message: Did you mean between you and me?
rule.example: Between you and I, there's no hope of survival.
Between you and me, there's no hope of cake tomorrow.

rule.name: every (ever) since
rule.example: And every since the war, the people have gone to bed at eleven.
Ever since the turn of the century, cows have worn hats.

rule.name: fowl (fell) swoop
rule.example: He completed the symphony in one fowl swoop.
He completed the symphony in one fell swoop.

rule.name: gardener (garter) snake
rule.example: We found a tiny gardener snake in the bushes.
We found a tiny garter snake in the bushes.

rule.name: hay day (heyday)
rule.example: He was never as good as he was in his hay day.
This was the boxer's heyday; he was fantastic.

rule.name: hardly never (ever)
rule.example: She hardly never takes the subway.
She hardly ever takes the subway.

rule.name: hew (hue) and cry
rule.message: Did you mean hue and cry?
rule.example: There was a massive hew and cry after the beating.
There was a massive hue and cry after the robbery.

rule.name: minus well (might as well)
rule.message: Did you mean might as well?
rule.example: We minus well break up.
We might as well break up.

rule.name: oft chance (off chance)
rule.example: On the oft chance that you get home by nine, could you turn on the oven?
On the off chance you're alive, could you call me?

rule.name: on the same token (by the same token)
rule.message: Did you mean by the same token?
rule.example: On the same token, they believe you've cheated them.
By the same token, they believe in faith before religion.

rule.name: one of the only (few)
rule.message: Did you mean one of the few?
rule.example: He's one of the only magicians in Providence.
She's one of the few musicians with an accordion.

rule.name: pedal to the medal (metal)
rule.message: Did you mean pedal to the metal?
rule.example: To get by the police car, he put the pedal to the medal.
To get by the cop car, he put the pedal to the metal.

rule.name: pawn off (palm off)
rule.example: Are you trying to pawn off that annoying client?
Are you trying to palm off that annoying client?

rule.name: plays a factor (plays a role)
rule.message: Did you mean plays a role?
rule.example: The goalie hardly plays a factor in the endgame.
The goalie hardly plays a role in the endgame.

rule.name: realms (realm) of possibility
rule.message: Did you mean realm of possibility?
rule.example: That is hardly outside the realms of possibility.
That's hardly outside the realm of possibility.

rule.name: sense of false security (false sense of security)
rule.message: Did you mean false sense of ?
rule.example: The members of the board were holding onto a sense of false security.
The members of the board were holding onto a false sense of security.

rule.name: ring (wring) its neck
rule.message: Did you mean wring its neck?
rule.example: I'm going to ring its neck.
I'm going to wring its neck.

rule.name: right (rite) of passage
rule.message: Did you mean rite of passage?
rule.example: The fire-ritual was a Cherokee right of passage.
The fire-ritual was a Cherokee rite of passage.

rule.name: rod (wrought) iron
rule.example: She specialized in art done in rod iron.
She specialized in wrought iron art.

rule.name: souse (sous) chef
rule.example: He gave most of his responsibility to his souse chef.
He gave most of his responsibility to his sous chef.

rule.name: stock and trade (stock in trade)
rule.message: Did you mean stock in trade?
rule.example: Swords and knives are their stock and trade.
Swords and bullion cubes are their stock in trade.

rule.name: sound byte (bite)
rule.example: The politician gave an awful sound byte.
The politician gave a great sound bite.

rule.name: to the manor (manner) born
rule.message: Did you mean to the manner born?
rule.example: He played the piano as to the manor born.
He played flute as to the manner born.

rule.name: vintage (vantage) point
rule.example: There was a great vintage point on the back side of the hill.
There was a great vantage point on the back of the hill.

rule.name: whim (wing) and a prayer
rule.message: Did you mean wing and a prayer?
rule.example: The Lakers appeared to be hanging on a whim and a prayer.
The Lakers appeared to be hanging on a whing and a prayer.

rule.name: year end (in) and year out
rule.message: Did you mean year in and year out?
rule.example: Year end and year out, we go out to the vineyards.
Year in and year out, we go to the vineyards.

rule.name: hand and hand (hand in hand)
rule.message: Did you mean hand in hand?
rule.example: The ability to talk forever goes hand and hand with being a Brown student.
The ability to talk about nothing important goes hand in hand with being a Brown student.

rule.name: grasping for straws (grasping at straws)
rule.message: Did you mean grasping at straws?
rule.example: At that point, the desperate gentleman was simply grasping for straws.
At the point it's just grasping at straws.

rule.name: grill (grilled) cheese
rule.example: The kid only wanted to eat grill cheese sandwiches.
The kid only wanted to eat grilled cheese sandwiches.

rule.name: might has (as) well
rule.message: Did you mean might as well?
rule.example: You might has well take off your shoes.
You might as well take off your shoes.

rule.name: on the contraire (au contraire)
rule.message: Did you mean au contraire or on the contrary?
rule.example: On the contraire, you've been following me home!
On the contrary, you've been following me home!

rule.name: damp squid (squib)
rule.example: The last firework of the evening was a disappointing damp squid.
The last firework of the evening was a disappointing damp squib.

rule.name: cursing (coursing) through veins
rule.message: Did you mean coursing through veins?
rule.example: It felt like the drugs were cursing through veins.
It felt like the drugs were coursing through veins.

rule.name: daring-do (derring-do)
rule.example: He impressed all the ladies with his daring-do.
He impressed all the ladies with his derring-do.

rule.name: death nail (knell)
rule.example: The fall of the Berlin Wall was the death nail for the USSR.
The fall of the Berlin Wall was the death knell for the USSR.

rule.name: reap what you sew (sow)
rule.message: Did you mean reap what you sow?
rule.example: You always reap what you sew.
You always reap what you sow.

rule.name: spare (spur) of the moment
rule.message: Did you mean spur of the moment?
rule.example: It was a spare of the moment decision.
It was a spur of the moment decision.

rule.name: tongue and (in) cheek
rule.message: Did you mean tongue in cheek?
rule.example: He said it with a fair amount of tongue and cheek.
She said it with a fair amount of tongue in cheek.

rule.name: urine analysis (urinalysis)
rule.example: They got the results of the urine analysis the next day.
They got the results of the urinalysis the next day.

rule.name: wet (whet) your appetite
rule.message: Did you mean whet your appetite?
rule.example: The first John Wayne movie will only serve to wet your appetite.
The first Woody Allen movie will only serve to whet your appetite.

rule.name: tattle-tail (tattle-tale)
rule.example: Every child hates a tattle-tail.
Every child hates a tattle-tale.

rule.name: old wise tail (old wives' tale)
rule.message: Did you mean old wives' tale?
rule.example: The story of the monster was only an old wise tail.
The story of the monster was only an old wives' tale.

rule.name: on the lamb (lam)
rule.message: Did you mean on the lam?
rule.example: The criminals spent most of the summer on the lamb.
The criminals spent most of the summer on the lam.

rule.name: youll will (you will)
rule.example: You'll will want to make sure you get the daily special.
You'll want to make sure you get some french fries.

rule.name: its is (it is)
rule.example: She's is the best dancer on the west coast.
She's the best dancer on the west coast.

rule.name: were are (we are)
rule.example: We're are the favorites to win the championship.
We are the favorites to win the championship.

rule.name: Im am (I am)
rule.example: I'm am a madman.
I am a prodigal son.

rule.name: Ive have (I have)
rule.example: I've have no problem taking the first watch.
I have no problem taking the first watch.

rule.name: Id would (I would)
rule.example: He'd would want to wake up early.
He'd want to wake up early.

rule.name: flashpoint (flash point)
rule.example: The flashpoint of lead is very high.
The flash point of lead is very high.

rule.name: can backup (back up)
rule.example: Did you know you can backup your data on an external drive?
The car can back up out of the driveway easily.

rule.name: can blackout (black out)
rule.message: Did you mean can black out?
rule.example: You can blackout if you have any more to drink.
You can black out if you have any more to drink.

rule.name: can setup (set up)
rule.example: She can setup the tent in thirty seconds.
She can set up the tent very quickly.

rule.name: can workout (work out)
rule.message: Did you mean can work out?
rule.example: We can workout after we get lunch.
We can work out after we eat lunch.

rule.name: got shutdown (shut down)
rule.example: Before he could get assigned to it, the project got shutdown.
Before he could cancel it, the project got shut down.

rule.name: got shutout (shut out)
rule.message: Did you mean got shut out?
rule.example: The Mets got shutout by the Phillies.
The Mets got shut out by the Yankees.

rule.name: in along (a long) time
rule.message: Did you mean in a long time?
rule.example: I haven't had a shower in along time.
I haven't had a bath in a long time.

rule.name: in anyway (any way)
rule.message: Did you mean in any way?
rule.example: Make sure you get the plans, in anyway possible.
Make sure you get the plans, in any way possible.

rule.name: incase (in case) of
rule.message: Did you mean in case of?
rule.example: Always keep a baseball bat by the bed, incase of an emergency.
Always keep a bat by the bed, in case of emergency.

rule.name: Portland Trailblazers (Trail Blazers)
rule.message: Did you mean Portland Trail Blazers?
rule.example: On Tuesday the Nets play the Portland Trailblazers.
On Tuesday the Nets play the Portland Trail Blazers.

rule.name: take awhile (a while)
rule.message: Did you mean take a while?
rule.example: I'm sorry sir, your laundry will take awhile longer.
I'm sorry, your laundry will take a while longer.

rule.name: to backout (back out)
rule.message: Did you mean to back out?
rule.example: There's still time to backout of the deal.
There's still time to back out of the deal.

rule.name: to blackout (black out)
rule.message: Did you mean to black out?
rule.example: He didn't want to blackout in front of his professor.
He didn't want to black out in front of the professor.

rule.name: to comeback (come back)
rule.example: The Mets gave the Yankees too much of a chance to comeback.
The Mets gave the Yankees too much of a chance to come back.

rule.name: along (a long) time
rule.message: Did you mean a long time?
rule.example: After along time the lovers were reunited.
A long time has passed since we last saw each other.

rule.name: downpayment (down payment)
rule.example: The couple made their first downpayment on their new house.
The couple made the first down payment on their new house.

rule.name: smartphone (smart phone)
rule.example: Susie wanted to get a smartphone to impress her boyfriend.
She couldn't type very well on her new smart phone.

rule.name: ala mode (a la mode)
rule.message: Did you mean à la mode?
rule.example: He loves his pie ala mode.
He loves his pie à la mode.

rule.name: afterall (after all)
rule.example: Afterall, there isn't any food to be had in this country.
After all, there isn't any food to be found in this country.

rule.name: whos NN (possessive)
rule.example: Do we know who's banana this is on the table?
Do we know whose banana this is on the table?

rule.name: whose DT (possessive)
rule.example: Whose the boss around here?
Who's the boss around here?

rule.name: about whos (possessive)
rule.example: What do you know about who's car that is?
What do you know about whose car that is?

rule.name: whos actual (possessive)
rule.example: Who's actual job is it to make copies around here?
Whose actual job is it to get coffee around here?

rule.name: don't will (won't)
rule.example: I don't will do that.
I won't do that.
Those who don't will never know.

rule.name: help to find (help find)
rule.message: This phrase is probably grammatically incorrect. Write help \2 find instead.
rule.example: Can any guru help me to find the reason?
Can any guru help me find the reason?

rule.message: Did you mean was or has been?
rule.example: She was been here since Monday.
She has been here since Monday.

rule.message: Did you mean was not or has not been?
rule.example: She was not been here since Monday.
She has not been here since Monday.

rule.message: Did you mean wasn't or hasn't been?
rule.example: She wasn't been here since Monday.
She hasn't been here since Monday.

rule.name: let's dont (let's not)
rule.message: Substandard usage of "let". The standard is: \1\2\3 not.
rule.example: Let's don't go there.
Let's not go there.

rule.name: these/those ones (these/those)
rule.message: This phrase is probably grammatically incorrect. Write \1 instead.
rule.example: These Ones Are Bitter.
These Are Bitter.

rule.name: 'each' or 'every' with plural nouns
rule.message: 'Each' and 'every' are used with singular. Did you mean all?
rule.example: Each children are happy.
Each children's services are available...
Each children services are available...
All children are happy.

rulegroup.name: Possible agreement error: plural noun + singular verb

rule.example: The dogs are released.
The dog is released.
The dogs barks loudly.
The dogs of war are released.
The dog of war is released.
The dogs of war barks loudly.
The dogs are released.
The dog is released.
The dogs is released.
The dogs were released.
The dog was released.
The dogs was released.

rule.message: Possible agreement error. You should probably use: are.
rule.example: The dogs of war are released.
The dog of war is released.
The dogs of war is released.

rule.message: Possible agreement error. You should probably use: were.
rule.example: The dogs of war are released.
The dog of war was released.
The dogs of war was released.

rule.name: Agreement: 'a' + plural word
rule.message: Don't use indefinite articles with plural words. Did you mean or simply ?
rule.example: I needed to use a text line as a criteria to select users for a list.
It is a criteria list that we prepared last night.
He was employed for a time by a Mrs. Reed.
There was a children's party at the Joneses yesterday.
I must have done that.
I must have wrote that.
I have liked her.
It has become difficult.
We have air conditioning.
We do not have soap.
We have soap.
We do have soap.
I could have wrote this letter.

rule.message: Possible agreement error -- use past participle here: .
rule.example: I have always done that.
I must have always wrote that.
I have always liked her.

rule.message: Possible agreement error – use past participle here: .
rule.example: I have like her.
I have liked her.

rule.message: Possible agreement error – use past participle here: .
rule.example: Have you like her?
Have you liked Dutch jazz music?
Have you seen her?

rule.message: Possible agreement error – use past participle here: .
rule.example: What have you did?
What have you seen?
Where have you were?

rule.message: Probably you should use a past participle here: .
rule.example: The software was introduce yesterday.
The program has been introduce.
The gift has been gave.
The park has been open for many years.
It has been done.
It has been love's whip.
He has been did this.

rule.message: Probably you should use a past participle here: .
rule.example: It has always been hated.
I must have been always wrote that.
The president was always hate in Moscow.
It has always been liked.

rulegroup.name: Agreement: Mass noun + non-third person verb

rule.message: Probably you should use third-person verb forms for singular and mass nouns: .
rule.example: Marketing are bad for you.
Marketing mean a lot of trouble.
Marketing is bad for you.
I think it is bad for you.

rule.message: Possible agreement error - use third-person verb forms for singular and mass nouns: .
rule.example: The marketing are bad for you.
The marketing is bad for you.
The city is an international transport hub and a popular tourist destination.
Those wanting are the Canines.

rulegroup.name: Agreement: 'I is / you is / ... ' (at sentence start only)

rule.message: Did you mean am or ate?
rule.example: I ate at the restaurant.
I am at the restaurant.
I are at the restaurant.

rule.message: Use second person verb with 'you': are or were.
rule.example: You are too old for that.
You is too old for that.

rule.message: Use third-person verb with '': or was.
rule.example: He is too old for that.
He were too old for that.
She were too old for that.

rule.message: Use first person plural verb with 'we': are, were.
rule.example: We are too old for that.
We is too old for that.

rule.message: Use third-person plural verb with 'they': are, were.
rule.example: They are too old for that.
They is too old for that.

rule.name: 'to' + non-base form
rule.message: You might need to use the base form of the verb here: .
rule.example: I was surprised to learn this.
He spoke to chosen people.
I was surprised to learns this.

rule.name: 'many/few' + uncountable noun, e.g. 'many (much) food'
rule.message: Use much or little with uncountable nouns.
rule.example: John eats as much food as Peter.
John eats as little food as Peter.
John eats as many food as Peter.
John eats as few food as Peter.

rule.name: Articles: a + uncountable noun
rule.message: Uncountable nouns are usually not used with an indefinite article. Use simply \2.
rule.example: The information in your files is correct.
An intelligence service is known to be corrupt here.
An accommodation is too expensive.

rule.name: Articles: 'most/some of' + plural noun
rule.message: After '\1 of', you should use 'the' (\1 \2 the \3) or simply say '\1 \3'.
rule.example: Most students do their homework.
Some of his students do their homework.
Most of students do their homework.
Buy a collection of most of Rand's works in a CD-ROM format.
Some of the students do their homework.

rule.example: He is friend.

rule.message: The article might be missing before the noun: .

rule.message: The article might be missing before the noun: .

rulegroup.name: 'afford', 'choose', 'deserve', 'pretend', 'strive' and 'struggle' used with gerund instead of infinitive

rulegroup.name: 'advise', 'help' and 'remind' used with gerund instead of infinitive

rule.message: Verbs 'advise' and 'remind' are used with infinitive: to .

rule.message: Verbs 'advise' and 'remind' are used with infinitive: to .

rule.message: The verb 'help' is used with infinitive: to or .

rule.message: The verb 'help' is used with infinitive: to .

rule.name: Superfluous article before 'much', e.g. 'a much work'
rule.message: Maybe you should omit the article "a", leaving only much.

rule.name: No 'more' or 'most' before superlatives
rule.message: Use only \2 (without '\1') when you use the superlative.
rule.example: Kyoto is the oldest city.
Kyoto is the most oldest city.

rule.name: No 'more' or 'most' before comparatives
rule.message: Use only \2 (without '\1') when you use the comparative.
rule.example: Kyoto is an older city.
Kyoto is a more older city.

rule.name: No indefinite article ('a'/'an') before superlatives

rule.message: The verb '' requires base form of the verb: .

rule.message: The verb '' requires base form of the verb: .

rule.name: 'must to' instead of 'have to'
rule.message: After 'must', the verb is used without 'to'. Probably, you should use must or have to here.

rule.name: Comparison with 'as'

rule.name: equally+as (equally)
rule.message: Don't say 'equally as'. You can use either equally or as on its own. When comparing two nouns, use just as.
rule.example: This model is equally as effective.

rule.message: This is a nonstandard phrase. Use .

rule.message: This is a nonstandard phrase. Use .

rule.name: if or not (whether or not)

It's not certain whether communication with the site's customer service has led it to be clear if or not this is true.

rule.name: 'kind/type/sort of a/an'
rule.message: Don't include '\3' after a classification term. Use simply \1 \2.

rule.name: 'the reason... is because'
rule.message: Probably an incorrect phrase. Use 'the reason is that'.

rule.name: because of we (because we)

rule.name: both... as well as (and)
rule.message: Probably usage error. Use and after 'both'.
rule.example: He is both rich and handsome.
He is both very rich as well as handsome.

rule.name: according to me (in my opinion)
rule.message: This phrase can sound awkward in English. Consider using in my opinion or I think.

rule.message: The noun should be probably in the plural form: .

rule.message: The noun should be probably in the plural form: .

rule.message: You probably should use this form here: the \3.

rulegroup.name: Wrong negated forms ('not... nothing' instead 'not... anything')

rule.message: Double negation. You probably should say .

rule.message: The adjective \1 is normally used with to.

rule.message: The adjective \1 is normally used with to and does not need 'more' (so called implicit comparative). Probably you need to write: \2 to.

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'today morning' (this morning)

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'yesterday night' (last night)
rule.message: This is a non-standard collocation. Normally, last night is used.

rule.name: Wrong phrase: 'today night' (tonight)
rule.message: This is a non-standard collocation. Normally, tonight is used instead.
rule.example: I'm going fishing today night.

rule.message: The currency mark is usually put at the beginning of the number: .

rule.name: Smart ellipsis (…)
rule.message: Use typographical ellipsis character here instead: ….

rule.name: shouldn't not (shouldn't)

rule.name: 'also' at the end of the sentence
rule.message: 'Also' is not used at the end of the sentence. Use as well instead.

rule.name: Duplicated 'the' surrounding an adverb

rule.name: an another (an / another)

rulegroup.name: Repetition of two words ('at the at the')

rule.message: 'Say' cannot be followed by a direct personal object. Did you mean tell?

rule.name: in the moment (currently)

rule.name: all and all (all in all)
rule.message: This phrase is nonstandard. Did you mean all in all (=after all, nevertheless)?

rule.name: all of the sudden (all of a sudden)
rule.message: This phrase is nonstandard. Did you mean all of a sudden?

rule.name: along the same vein (along the same line, in the same vein)
rule.message: This phrase is nonstandard. Use in the same vein or along the same line.

example.correction: in the same vein|along the same line

rule.name: Misused phrase: 'ever so often (every so often)'
rule.message: This phrase is non-standard in most writing. Did you mean every \2 \3?

rule.name: early adapter (early adopter)

rule.name: far be it for me (far be it from me)

rule.name: money is no option (money is no object)

rule.name: nip it in the butt (nip it in the bud)
rule.message: Did you mean nip it in the bud (=stop it from flowering completely)?
rule.example: We'd like to nip it in the butt right here.
We'd like to nip it in the bud right here.

rule.name: now and days (nowadays)
rule.example: Money is becoming pretty tight now and days.
Money is becoming pretty tight nowadays.

rule.name: the proof is in the pudding (the proof of the pudding is in the eating)
rule.message: If you don't want to look for proofs hidden in your pudding, you probably meant the proof of the pudding is in the eating.

example.correction: The proof of the pudding is in the eating
example.marker: The Proof Is In The Pudding

rule.example: The proof of the pudding is in the eating.

rule.name: qui bono (cui bono)
rule.message: Non standard Latin. Did you mean cui bono (=to whose benefit).
rule.example: Let me ask: qui bono?
Let me ask: cui bono?

rule.name: whip cream (whipped cream)
rule.example: Whip cream until it becomes whip cream.
Whip cream until it becomes whipped cream.

rule.name: in regards to (regarding, with regard to)
rule.message: Use simply regarding or with regard to.
rule.example: Please be aware of the following changes in regards to this program.
Please be aware of the following changes in this program.

rule.name: very known (very well-known, well-known)
rule.message: Incorrect phrase. Use very well-known or well-known instead.
rule.example: He is a very known actor.
He is a well-known actor.

rule.name: an invite (invitation)
rule.message: Use only in informal register. In other registers, invitation should be used.
rule.example: Is that an invite...?
Is that an invitation...?

rule.message: This phrase is redundant ('M' stands for 'machine'). Use simply \1.
rule.example: ATM Machine Comparison Guide
ATM Comparison Guide

rule.message: This phrase is redundant ('M' stands for 'machine'). Use simply \1s.
rule.example: In the Netherlands, criminals are stealing money from ATM machines by blowing them up.
ATMs are quite common in the Netherlands,

rule.name: absolutely essential/necessary (essential/necessary)
rule.example: This is absolutely essential.
This was essential.

rule.name: actual experience/facts (experience/facts)
rule.example: This talk is based on actual experience gained during recovery operations following a fire at the Washington National Records.
This play is based on facts.

rule.name: advance planning/preview/reservations/warning (planning/preview/reservations/warning)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Use simply \2.
rule.example: Advance planning is one strategy couples can use to establish legal rights.
Planning is one strategy couples can use to establish legal rights.

rule.name: add an additional (add)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Use simply .
rule.example: How to Add an Additional Page to a Full Flash Site
How to Add a Page to a Full Flash Site
It's 5 AM in the morning.
It's 5 AM.
He doesn't know where I am in the morning.
It's 5 A.M. in the morning.
It's 5 A.M.
It's 5 PM in the evening.
It's 5 PM.
It's 1 PM at night.
It's 5 PM.
It's 5 P.M. in the afternoon.
It's 5 P.M.
It's 1 P.M. at night.
It's 5 P.M.

rule.name: and also (and/also)
rule.example: Typical English Food and also Welsh and Scottish too
Typical English Food, and Welsh and Scottish too

rule.name: and etc. (etc.)
rule.example: E-Commerce and etc.
E-Commerce etc.

rule.name: annual anniversary (anniversary)
rule.example: First Annual Anniversary Contest
First Anniversary Contest

rule.name: added bonus (bonus)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Use simply \2.
rule.example: Added bonus: booting from cdrom.
Bonus: booting from CD-ROM.

rule.name: ask the question (ask)
rule.example: He asked the question.
He asked the question whether it's OK to add some rules to LanguageTool.

rule.name: as of yet (yet)
rule.message: Use simply yet or as yet.
rule.example: The report remains unfinished as of yet.
The report remains unfinished as yet.

rule.name: armed gunman (gunman)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Use simply \2.
rule.example: Armed gunmen entered the room to kill Bill.
Gunmen are very dangerous in this city.

rule.name: attach/assemble together (attach/assemble)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Use simply \1 instead.
rule.example: Reelin molecules assemble together to form a large protein complex.
Reelin molecules assemble to form a large protein complex

rule.name: autobiography of a life (autobiography)
rule.example: In this autobiography of a life of courage and love, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles.
In this story of a life of courage and love, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles

rule.name: basic fundamentals/necessities (fundamentals/necessities)
rule.example: Visual Basic Fundamentals
Let’s get back to the basic fundamentals!

rule.name: bald-headed (bald)
rule.example: He is bald-headed.
Kojak was bald.

rule.name: balsa wood (balsa)
rule.example: It's made of balsa wood.
This table is made of balsa.

rule.name: bare naked (naked)
rule.example: The old man ran bare naked through the streets.
The old man ran naked through the streets.

rule.name: best ever (best)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Use simply \1.
rule.example: Top ten best ever beer names.
Top ten best beer names.

rule.name: bitter in taste (bitter)
rule.example: This beer is bitter.
This beer is bitter in taste.

rule.name: blend together (blend)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Use simply \1.
rule.example: Their voices blend together in lovely harmony.
Their voices blend in lovely harmony.

rule.name: boat marina (marina)
rule.example: Taupo Boat Marina
Taupo Marina

rule.name: brief in duration (brief)
rule.example: However, most wilderness programs are brief in duration.
However, most wilderness programs are brief.

rule.name: brief moment/summary (moment/summary)
rule.example: A Brief Moment of Compassion
A Moment of Compassion

rule.name: biography of her life (biography)
rule.example: In this biography of her life, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles.
In this story of a life of courage and love, we get to share in the compelling story of a family’s struggles

rule.name: bouquet of flowers (bouquet)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Use simply \1.
rule.example: What a beautiful bouquet of flowers!
What a beautiful bouquet!

rule.name: but nevertheless/however (but)
rule.example: I should not have, but nevertheless I did.
I should not have, but I did.

rule.name: CD disc (disc)
rule.example: I ordered a CD disk with their software.
I ordered a CD with their software.

rule.name: close scrutiny/proximity (scrutiny/proximity)
rule.example: Their manifesto yesterday received the same close scrutiny as the other two big parties — and it was an uncomfortable experience.
Their manifesto yesterday received the same scrutiny as the other two big parties — and it was an uncomfortable experience.

rule.name: comfortable with doing (comfortable doing)
rule.example: I am not comfortable with dancing with strangers.
I am not comfortable dancing with strangers.

rule.name: common bond (bond)
rule.example: They formed a common bond against the British
They formed a bond against the British

rule.name: commute back and forth (commute)
rule.example: She will commute back and forth between New Haven and her home in Southern California before relocating to the Elm City this summer.
She will commute between New Haven and her home in Southern California before relocating to the Elm City this summer

rule.name: consensus of opinion (consensus)
rule.example: Wim Duisenberg, the ECB's Dutch president, is seen as a leader who seeks to fashion a consensus of opinion on the council rather than imposing his own views, as some chairmen of the US Federal Reserve have done.

Wim Duisenberg, the ECB's Dutch president, is seen as a leader who seeks to fashion a consensus on the council rather than imposing his own views, as some chairmen of the US Federal Reserve have done.

rule.name: continue to remain (remain)
rule.example: We continued to remain optimistic.
We remain optimistic.

rule.name: descend down (descend)
rule.message: This phrase might be redundant. Use simply \1.
rule.example: The Pentagon aides and journalists descend down the back stairs of the plane as is customary while Rumsfeld comes down the main stairs to meet his welcome party.
The Pentagon aides and journalists descend the back stairs of the plane as is customary while Rumsfeld comes down the main stairs to meet his welcome party.

rule.name: during the course of (during)
rule.example: He never smiled during the course of the trial.
He never smiled during the trial.

rule.name: each and every one (each one)
rule.example: God bless each and every one of you!
God bless each one of you!

rule.name: every now and then (now and then)
rule.example: Every now and then the faucet drips.
Now and then the faucet drips.

rule.name: established fact (fact)
rule.example: This is an established fact.
This is a fact.

rule.name: exactly the same/identical (the same/identical)
rule.example: This shoe is exactly the same.
This shoe is the same.

rule.name: exact same/identical (same/identical)
rule.example: This is the exact same situation.
This is the same situation.

rule.name: fall season (fall)
rule.example: The leaves turn red and gold in the fall season.
The leaves turn red and gold in fall.

rule.name: famous celebrity (celebrity)
rule.example: I'm told that he's a famous celebrity now.
I'm told that he's a celebrity now.

rule.name: fellow classmates/co-workers/comrades (classmates/co-workers/comrades)
rule.example: I would enjoy a reunion with my fellow classmates.
I would enjoy a reunion with my classmates.

rule.name: few in number (few)
rule.example: They were few in number, but mighty.
They were few, but mighty.

rule.name: first time ever (first time)
rule.example: We have a pig in space for the first time ever.
We have a pig in space for the first time.

rule.name: foreign import (import)
rule.message: This phrase is redundant. Use simply \2.
rule.example: The rise in foreign imports, the argument goes, is forcing some Americans to accept lower pay to remain competitive with, say, Mexican and Chinese workers.
The rise in imports, the argument goes, is forcing some Americans to accept lower pay to remain competitive with, say, Mexican and Chinese workers.

rule.name: forever and ever (forever)
rule.example: It is you and me, forever and ever.
It is you and me, forever.

rule.name: from whence (whence)
rule.example: Go back from whence you came.
Go back whence you came!

rule.name: honest truth (truth)
rule.example: That is the honest truth of the matter.
That is the truth of the matter.

rule.name: in order to (to)
rule.message: This phrase might be considered redundant. Use simply \3.
rule.example: We opened the door in order to enter.
We opened the door to enter.

rule.name: introduce for the first time (introduce)
rule.example: We were introduced for the first time a week ago.
We were introduced a week ago.

rule.name: main focus (focus)
rule.example: Redundancies are the main focus of my essay.
Redundancies are the focus of my essay.

rule.name: major breakthrough (breakthrough)
rule.example: It was a major breakthrough in genetic research.
It was a breakthrough in genetic research.

rule.name: can/could/may/might possibly (can/could/may/might)
rule.example: That may possibly be the greatest blunder of all.
That may be the greatest blunder of all.

rule.name: mental telepathy (telepathy)
rule.example: Do cats really use mental telepathy?
Do cats really use telepathy?

rule.name: mutually dependent on each other (mutually dependent)
rule.example: Well, they're mutually dependent on each other.
Well, they're mutually dependent.

rule.name: never at any time (never)
rule.example: I was never at any time with that woman.
I was never with that woman.

rule.name: now currently (now)
rule.example: She is now currently the ambassador.
She is now the ambassador.

rule.name: one and the same (the same)
rule.example: Santa Claus and Saint Nick are one and the same person.
Santa Claus and Saint Nick are the same person.

rule.name: or alternatively (or)
rule.example: We can either do this now or alternatively leave it for tomorrow.
We can either do this now or leave it for tomorrow.

rule.name: passing fad (fad)
rule.example: Computers are just a passing fad.
Computers are just a fad.

rule.name: past experience/memory (experience/memory)
rule.example: We know from past experience that weakness breeds contempt.
We know from experience that weakness breeds contempt.

rule.name: period of time (period)
rule.example: Horses were absent throughout that period of time.
Horses were absent throughout that period.

rule.name: personal charm/belongings/opinion/friendship (charm/belongings/opinion/belongings)
rule.example: In my personal opinion, canaries are quite tasty.
In my opinion, canaries are quite tasty.

rule.name: point being is that (point is that/point being that)
rule.example: The point being is that Russia and Japan weren't even at war.
The point is that Russia and Japan weren't even at war

rule.name: reason why (reason)
rule.example: The reason why I did that is simple.
The reason I did that is simple.

rule.name: so therefore (therefore)
rule.example: I am me, the only me, so therefore I am unique, which in turn makes me special :)
I am me, the only me, so I am unique, which in turn makes me special :)

rule.name: therapeutic treatment (treatment)
rule.example: My swelled knee required special therapeutic treatment.
My swelled knee required special treatment.

rule.name: rustic country (rustic)
rule.example: She loved her rustic country kitchen.
She loved her rustic kitchen.

rule.name: safe haven (haven)
rule.example: They ran for the forest, searching for a safe haven.
They ran for the forest, searching for a haven.

rule.name: same identical (same)
rule.example: They wore the same identical dress.
They wore the same dress.

rule.name: usual custom (custom)
rule.example: Eggnog on Christmas is our usual custom.
Eggnog on Christmas is our custom.

rule.name: very unique (unique)
rule.example: Walk until you see the very unique building on your right.
Walk until you see a unique building on your right.

rule.name: whether or not (whether)
rule.message: In most contexts, this phrase is redundant and can be replaced with \1. However, it is correct if you mean 'regardless of whether'.
rule.example: What the government decides to do depends on whether or not the bill passes.
What the government decides to do depends on whether the bill passes.

rule.name: Number starting a sentence
rule.message: Numbers at the start of the sentence should be written as words.
rule.example: 12 soldiers were killed!
Twelve soldiers were killed!

rule.name: Word order: 'Hopefully' starting a sentence
rule.message: Many style books advice that a sentence should not start with 'hopefully'.
rule.example: Hopefully, this will be a great grammar checker.
The prisoner thought hopefully about the prospect for escape.

rule.name: Readability: Three nouns in a row
rule.message: You used three nouns after one another, and this might decrease readability. You might consider rewording the sentence.
rule.example: The security protection software we offer is the state-of-the art achievement.
The security software we offer is the state-of-the art achievement.

rule.message: The word \1 probably should be uppercase: .
rule.example: My name is susan.
My name is Susan.

rule.message: This should be written in uppercase: I.
rule.example: Who do you think i am?
Who do you think I am?

rule.message: The word \3 should probably be written in uppercase: .
rule.example: This is a story from “atlantic monthly”.
This is a story from “The Atlantic Monthly”.

rule.message: The word \1 should probably be uppercase:.
rule.example: Eve sobol, Indiana
Eve Sobol, Indiana

rule.message: The word \1 should probably be uppercase: .
rule.example: This is susan.
This is Susan.
